captions.text:
>> Welcome back to SourceFed, I'm William
Haynes. Come fly with me Internet. On a time

machine. We're going on a journey way back
to the year 1 thousand nine-hundred and 96.
[music]

>> Ah! Here we are in the year 1996, what's
the greatest thing that happened this year?

King Fahd of Saudi Arabia temporarily giving
power to Crown Prince Abdullah his legal successor
due to his illness? No.

>> The element copernicium is discovered?
Poppycock. The first episode of Blues Clues?
That's what I'm talking about.

>> For those of you who don't know Blues Clues
was a children's television series that ran

from 1996 to 2006 and kind of shaped the early
life of most millennials because cute dog
blue that was actually a girl.

>> Shout out to Nickelodeon for smashing gender
roles and the patriarchy with that one. Shockingly,

a little over halfway through its run the
shows star, local schizophrenic, and fellow
sweater enthusiast Steve, left the show.

>> When this happened roomers spread faster
than my ex-wife's legs when a basketball player's
in the room. Really fast.

>> With almost no real media attention we
were almost left in the dark about his whereabouts.

On the show it was said that Steve "went to
college" but even 8 year old me knew that
wasn't true.

>> Steve lived alone and had a dog! He can't
afford college loans! He'd be in debt out

the wazoo until 2037! Then everyone began
to say that Steve died of a drug overdose,

and to be honest, Steve doesn't seem like
the kind of guy to eff around with heavy drugs.

>> Obviously the shows are just the rendered
trips Steve goes on while taking a dose of

shrooms or acid, I highly doubt he'd move
on to the heavy stuff like heroine.

>> In the real world were sadly salt and pepper
shakers don't talk and you have to walk all

the way to your unanimated mailbox only to
receive bills instead of letters from random

people, Steve went on the record of giving
a few reasons for his departure including
continuing his music career.

>> Which makes me mad because I only know
like 2 of his songs: "We just got a letter"

and "Blue skidoo we can too" neither of which
made it to billboards top 100! Clearly the
radio is being run by cultureless swine.

>> Burns stated that the main reason he left
the show was actually because he was going

bald. In the Nickelodeon special "Behind the
Clues: 10 Years with Blue," he said, "I knew

I wasn't going to be doing children's television
all my life.

>> Mostly because I refused to lose my hair
on a kids TV show and it was happening fast."

Since the show Steve has done a few acting
gigs and created an album called "Songs for

dust mites" which sounds like something I
can relate to.

>> But I know I speak for my generation when
I say thank you to Steve for teaching us we

can do anything that we want to do as he sang
at the ever single episode kind of like brainwash.
But it worked.

>> For all of you folks at home, what was
your favorite kids show and why? Is that a
clue? I got to go.

title: What Ever Happened To Steve From Blues Clues?

comments.text:
+Stéphenia Echem haha okay, thanks for the background info :D! But i dont 
understand why parents would ban their kids from watching Caillou just cuz 
they thought he has cancer. :/ ! Even if he did, it'd be an educational 
show for kids.
comments.author: Minahli x

comments.text:
Ha… no, Caillou did not have cancer. He was bald because in the books he 
was nine months old, but his cartoon aged him to four years old… the 
creators did not add hair to his head just for him to represent a child. 
Some parents actually banned their kids from watching the show because they 
didn't want their kids watching "a kid with cancer."

So, your childhood is not ruined, but Caillou was supposed to be nine 
months old… LOL. +Minahli x

comments.text:
My favorite little kid T.V. shows were Blue's Clues, Dragon Tales, The 
Doodlebops, Johnny and the Sprites, and Imagination Movers. Yes, I was born 
at a time (2002) to have been able to watch both sets of shows as a little 
kid.  I was old enough to catch the endings of the series to Blue's Clues, 
Dragon Tales, The Doodlebops, and Johnny and the Sprites when I was like, 
2-6 years old, and young enough to still been able to watch Imagination 
Movers when I was 4-8 years old.﻿
